user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_param__connections:
```c
static int
check_param__connections (void)
{
  if (0 == tool_params.connections)
    return ! 0;
  if (get_num_threads () > tool_params.connections)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "The connections number limit (%u) is less than number "
             "of threads used (%u). Use higher value for connections limit.\n",
             tool_params.connections, get_num_threads ());
    return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments selected are the conditional returns and the final return that determine control flow; these are the locations where unreachable code could arise (for example if the conditions can be resolved at compile time or by constants, making some branches impossible). Other pieces of the function (the string literal concatenation in fprintf, the fprintf call arguments syntax, whitespace and braces, and the function signature) are normal constructs that do not by themselves introduce unreachable code and therefore do not require further investigation for Rule 2.1 in this function. No statements occur syntactically after an unconditional return within the same block (other than the separate conditional branches already reported), so there are no additional obvious unreachable-code suspects in this snippet.
